name: NHL 25 Neutral Zone System Tree
description: Canonical neutral zone system tree for NHL 25. Only uses in-game options: 1-2-2 Red, 1-2-2 Blue, 1-3-1, and 1-4. This file defines what each system does, when to use it, and how it interacts with the Trap Forecheck slider (0–6).

notes: No custom names are allowed here. All system names MUST match the NHL 25 UI exactly.
Matchup/gameplan outputs must only use these four neutral zone options.
Aggression level is controlled by both the system choice AND the Trap Forecheck slider (0–6).

1-2-2 Red.label: 1-2-2 Red
1-2-2 Red.description: Balanced, pressure-capable neutral zone setup that pressures the puck carrier more aggressively than 1-2-2 Blue while still having decent structure.
strengths: Good against teams that prefer controlled entries.
Can force dump-ins without completely turtling.
Solid for mid-skill or rush-balanced opponents.
weaknesses: Can open small seams if the trap slider is set too high.
If F1 overcommits, can be vulnerable to quick middle support.

1-2-2 Blue.label: 1-2-2 Blue
1-2-2 Blue.description: More conservative, trap-focused version of the 1-2-2. Designed to clog lanes and slow teams down in the neutral zone.
strengths: Excellent for locking down leads late in games.
Very strong vs high-speed rush teams that rely on controlled entries.
weaknesses: Can concede more controlled dumps and zone time if used while trailing.
If overused, may reduce your own transition offence.

1-3-1.description: High-control neutral zone look that packs three players across the middle. Excellent at forcing dump-ins and killing rush lanes.
strengths: Best choice against elite rush players that attack the middle of the ice.
Excellent for limiting cross-lane passes in the neutral zone.
Strong structure when protecting the slot line.
weaknesses: If trap slider is too low, can sit back too far and invite zone time.
Can be overrun by heavy dump-and-chase, grindy teams.

1-4.description: Ultra-defensive neutral zone scheme (full trap look). One forechecker high with four players stacked deep to block all rush lanes.
strengths: Maximum shutdown option when protecting a lead late.
Extremely effective at denying controlled entries.
Excellent for closing out games when you want no odd-man rushes against.
weaknesses: Very little offense generated off the rush.
Can concede heavy zone time if used too early or while trailing.
Not ideal if you need quick goals.

notes: Shift to 1-4 with low trap value in last 5–10 minutes if opponent is pushing hard.
Use 1-2-2 Blue as default, 1-3-1 vs elite rushers.
Consider 1-4 only very late if protecting a lead.
1-3-1 vs teams that live off the rush.
Use higher trap slider values to push more forecheck pressure while still in 1-2-2 Red.
Focus on denying middle ice and forcing low-percentage dump-ins.
Drop trap value toward 1–3 to slow them without giving up too much pressure.
Balanced approach, let your DZ coverage handle their cycle.
Trap value can stay around 3–4 for balanced resistance.
You don’t need to turtle; play balanced and let talent win.
Push trap value up slightly if they start gaining too many clean entries.

forecheck_link.note: Neutral zone choice works together with forecheck type (1-2-2 Passive, 1-2-2 Aggressive, 2-3, Weak Side Lock) and Trap Forecheck slider.

slider_model_link.note: Trap Forecheck slider (0–6) uses the trap_forecheck_slider definition from the global slider model.
